Kristof's review of energy options is accurate as far as it goes, but it doesn't mention possibly the most promising and ecologically sound long-term energy source: tidal hydropower, based on underwater turbines at any place where water regularly flows, whether rivers (one-way flow) or the tides (two-way).

Nicholas D. Kristof's review of energy options is accurate as far as it goes, but it doesn't mention possibly the most promising and ecologically sound long-term energy source: tidal hydropower, based on underwater turbines at any place where water regularly flows, whether rivers (one-way flow) or the tides (two-way).
No dams are required, with their many environmental problems, especially to fish and other wildlife. No fossil fuels are expended, and there is not likely to be another Chernobyl.
John M. Ellis New York, April 9, 2005
